pr_title: IGNITE-12549 fix mapping queries on replication cache during rebalance

timeline.message: IGNITE-12549 fix mapping queries on replication cache during rebalance

timeline.bodyText: I worry about a case when there is no node OWNING all partitions (i.e. actually some partitions are lost). In a such case we will use all affinity nodes for a query execution. And duplicates seems possible. I suggest at least resort to any (single) affinity node in such case. And it looks like the previous behavior was the same.
timeline.author: pavlukhin

replies.bodyText:
Why do you think it will cause duplicates?
I supposed if I return all affinity nodes it will try to use only primary partitions in this case, like if we worked with PARTITIONED cache, correct me if I'm wrong.
replies.author: macrergate

replies.bodyText: I meant for each partition distributed query manager will choose only primary node for this partition, thus no duplicate results possible. Otherwise if I'll return one affinity node in such case, it certainly will lead to incomplete results. Do you agree?
replies.author: macrergate

replies.bodyText: I can see from GridCacheQueryManager#scanIterator backup partitions will be always scanned for REPLICATED caches. And I still think that it should be evident from code that only one node is used for query execution against REPLICATED cache.
replies.author: pavlukhin

replies.bodyText:
Also I dug a little bit deeper and found some more problems.
First, there is a race between getting nodes and inspecting partitions. Consequently cctx.topology().partitions(node.id()) can return null here. I suppose using single topology version here can help.
Second, LOST partitions are not handled properly. It is possible that hasMovingPartitions returns false when there are LOST partitions. Unpleasant, but in my mind can be fixed in a separate ticket about ScanQuery and LOST partitions.
Good news here are that if there is no LOST partitions it seems there is an invariant for REPLICATED caches that on a specific topology version at least one node owns all partitions.
replies.author: pavlukhin

replies.bodyText:
Hi, Ivan. I agree LOST partitions case better to solve in another ticket.
About the race - I did not realize how to use topology version here, but it looks like I solved the race with topology.readLock(), how do you like it?
replies.author: macrergate
